article.headline: Just 3 in 10 people working outside the home get hazard pay, despite âpervasive fearâ of bringing coronavirus home
article.body: For many people heading in to work during the COVID-19 pandemic, the rewards havenât kept pace with the perceived risks, a new analysis suggests. More than half of workers leaving their homes to go to work say theyâre concerned about exposing their households to the coronavirus, but just 30% are compensated with hazard pay, according to a new report by the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank. About 27% of white people, 41% of black people and 34% of Hispanic people working outside the home receive hazard pay. The study commissioned questions on a recent YouGov poll and also wrapped in survey findings from the National Employment Law Project (NELP), the progressive Roosevelt Institute and other sources. It defined hazard pay as when workers âreceived extra pay or benefits because of the higher risks you faceâ as either a one-time bonus or payment, a change in wage rate or another type of financial benefit. “ âWorkers are thus being forced to make unacceptable choices between economic sustenance and their health and their familyâs health, a squeeze targeted at those with the least power in the labor market.â ” â report by the Economic Policy Institute âThere is pervasive fear among workers of bringing the coronavirus home from work, especially among vulnerable workers with the least bargaining power, such as Black and Hispanic workers and low- and middle-income workers,â wrote the authors. âThese workers are not being protected by OSHA-established standards and they are also not receiving additional compensation in proportion to the risks they face.â Workers of color are overrepresented in essential jobs that require them to commute to work outside the home, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention note. One Washington Post-Ipsos survey included in the EPI analysis found that 72% of Hispanic workers and 68% of black workers employed outside of their homes worried about exposure to COVID-19 on the job and subsequent infection of household members, compared to 50% of white workers. Racial disparities also emerged in responses to a separate NELP survey, which asked, âHave you gone to work outside your home during this pandemic, even though you thought it might be seriously risking your health or a family memberâs health?â Some 73% of black respondents and 64% of Hispanic respondents replied âyesâ to the question, versus 49% of white respondents. The HEROES Act passed by the Democrat-controlled House last month would provide up to $10,000 in âpandemic premium payâ for essential workers. Many employees are âbeing forced to work in order to sustain their families, and many are being denied unemployment benefits for not being willing to go to jobs they consider unsafe,â the EPI reportâs authors wrote. âWorkers are thus being forced to make unacceptable choices between economic sustenance and their health and their familyâs health, a squeeze targeted at those with the least power in the labor market,â they said. âPolicies to protect workersâ health on the job as well as to provide decent pay and income maintenance are essential.â
